Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Hello, Mrs. MacGruder, have you ever seen so many gulls?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What do you suppose it is?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: You said three o'clock.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well, this one won't be a chick, will he?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: And he'll talk?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well, all right, but...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I wonder if you could help me.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I said I wonder if you could help me.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, what was it you were looking for, sir?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Lovebirds.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Lovebirds, sir?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes. I understand there are different varieties, it that true?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well... yes, sir, there are.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: These are for my sister... her birthday you see. As she'll be eleven and... well, frankly, I wouldn't want a pair of birds that were too demonstrative.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I understand completely, sir.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: As the same time, I wouldn't want birds that were aloof, either.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, of course not.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Do you have a pair that are just friendly?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I think so, sir.  Now then, let me see.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Aren't these lovebirds?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, sir, those are... redbirds.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: The sign says strawberry finches.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Those are canaries, Miss.  Doesn't this make you feel awful?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Doesn't what make me...?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: All these innocent little creatures caged up like this?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well, we can't just let them fly around the shop, you know.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I suppose not. Is there an ornithological reason for keeping them in separate cages?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh, certainly. It's to protect the species.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I imagine that's very important. Especially during the moulting season.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, that's a particularly dangerous time.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Are they moulting now?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Some of them are.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: How can you tell?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well... they get a sort of hangdog expression.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes, I see.  About those lovebirds, Miss...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Are you sure you wouldn't like to see a canary instead? We have some very nice canaries this week.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: All right.  She smiles back.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: All right, may I see one, please?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Here, birdie. Here, birdie, birdie.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh!  Ohhhhh!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Shhh! Shhhh!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: There we are!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Back into your gilded cage, Melanie Daniels.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What did you say?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I was merely drawing a parallel, Miss Daniels.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: But how... how do you know my name?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Hey, wait a minute!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I don't know you.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Ahhh, but I know you.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: How?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: We met in court.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: We never met in court or anyplace else.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: That's true. I'll rephrase it. I saw you in court.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: When?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Do you remember one of your practical jokes that resulted in the smashing of a plate glass window?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I didn't break that window!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: No, but your little prank did. The judge should have put you behind bars!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What are you? A policeman?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I simply believe in the law, Miss Daniels, and I'm not too keen on practical jokers.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What do you call your lovebird story if not a practical...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Ahhh, but I really do want those birds.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: You knew I didn't work here. You deliberately...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Right. I recognized you when I came in. I thought you might like to know what it felt like to be on the other end of a gag. What do you think of that, Miss Daniels?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I think you're a louse.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: And I'm glad you didn't get your lovebirds!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: See you in court some day.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: That... that... who was that?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Have you got a pencil?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, you'd better send him. May I use your phone?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Do you have any lovebirds?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: How soon?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Immediately.  Is this the Daily News? Melanie Daniels. Would you get me the city desk, please?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Now. What time tomorrow morning?

Speaker: man's voice
Dialogue: Miss...?  She stops, distressed.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Is that for Mitch Brenner?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: He's not home.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: That's all right.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: He won't be back until Monday. I mean, if those birds are for him....

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Monday?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Yes. I don't think you should leave them in the hall, do you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well, I...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well, where did he go?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Bodega Bay. He goes up there every weekend.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Bodega Bay? Where's that?

Speaker: man
Dialogue: Up on the coast. About sixty miles north of here.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Sixty...  Oh.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: About an hour and a half on the freeway. Or two if you take the coast highway.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I'd hold the birds for him, but I'm going away myself. Someone's got to feed them, I suppose.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes. Yes, someone's got to feed them.

Speaker: man
Dialogue: I'm awfully sorry.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh, shut up!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Morning.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I wonder if you could help me.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Try my best.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'm looking for a man named Mitchell Brenner.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Do you know him?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yep.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Where does he live?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Right here. Bodega Bay.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, but where?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Right across the bay there.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Where?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: See where I'm pointing?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: The Brenners? Mr. and Mrs. Brenner?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Nope, just Lydia and the two kids.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: The two kids?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yep. Mitch and the little girl.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I see. How do I get down there?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Follow the road straight through town 'til it curves off on the left. That'll take you right around the bay to their front door.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: The front door.  Isn't there a back road I can take?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Nope. That's the road. Straight through town, stay on your left, right around the bay to the front door.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: You see, I wanted to surprise them.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Mmmm.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I didn't want to come right down the road, where they could see me.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Mmmm.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It's a surprise, you see.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Mmmmmm.  'Course, you could get yourself a boat, cut right across the bay with it. The Brenners got a little dock there you could tie up at. If that's what you wanted to do.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Where would I get a boat?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Down at the dock by the Tides Restaurant. Ever handled an outboard boat?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Of course.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: D'you want me to order one for you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: What name?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Daniels.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I wonder if you could tell me...

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yep?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: The little girl's name.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: The little Brenner girl?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Alice, I think.  Harry, what's the little Brenner girl's name?

Speaker: harry's voice
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: The little Brenner girl.

Speaker: harry's voice
Dialogue: Lois!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: It's Alice, ain't it?

Speaker: harry's voice
Dialogue: No, it's Lois!

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: It's Alice.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Well, I ain't positive, if that's what you mean.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I need her exact name, you see.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: That case, I tell you what you do. You go straight through town 'til you see a little hotel on your left there. Not the motel, that's the other end of town. This is the hotel. Now you take a right turn there, you got that?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Near the top of the hill, you'll see the school and right behind it, the church. You head for the school. Now just past the school, you'll see a little house with a red mail box. That's where Annie Hayworth lives, she's the school teacher. You ask her about the little Brenner girl.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Yep.  Could save yourself a lot of trouble. Her name's Alice for sure.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Can I have the boat in about twenty minutes?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: How much for the phone calls?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: It's nothing.

Speaker: annie's voice
Dialogue: Yes? Who is it?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Me!

Speaker: annie's voice
Dialogue: Who's me?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Miss Hayworth?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'm Melanie Daniels. I'm sorry to bother you, but...

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: The man at the post office sent me. He said you'd know the name of the little Brenner girl.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Cathy?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: The one who lives in the white house across the bay?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: That's the one. Cathy Brenner.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: They seemed sure it was either Alice or Lois.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Which is why the mail in this town never gets delivered to the right place.  Did you want to see Cathy about something?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well... not exactly.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Are you a friend of Mitch's?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, not really.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I've been wanting a cigarette for the past twenty minutes, but I couldn't convince myself to stop. This 'tilling of the soil' can get a little compulsive, you know.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It's a lovely garden.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Thank you. It gives me something to do with my spare time.  Did you plan on staying long?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No. Just a few hours.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: You're leaving after you see Cathy?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well... something like that.  I'm sorry. I don't mean to sound so mysterious.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Actually, it's none of my business.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I'd better get on my way. Thank you very much.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Not at all.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Did you drive up from San Francisco?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: It's a nice drive.  Is that where you met Mitch?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I guess that's where everyone meets him.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Now you sound a bit mysterious, Miss Hayworth.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Do I?  Pretty. What are they?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Lovebirds.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Mmm.  Well, good luck, Miss Daniels.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: That was the damndest thing I ever saw.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What made it...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: It deliberately came down at you -- you're bleeding...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Come on, let's take care of that.

Speaker: fisherman
Dialogue: What happened, Mitch?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: A gull hit her.

Speaker: fisherman
Dialogue: A what?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Come on, we'd better go up to the restaurant.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Deke, have you got a first aid kit back there?

Speaker: deke
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Young woman cut herself.

Speaker: deke
Dialogue: Shall I call the doctor?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I don't think it's that serious. You want to sit up here?

Speaker: deke
Dialogue: You cut yourself outside, Miss?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Stop worrying, Deke. She was in a boat.

Speaker: deke
Dialogue: I had a man trip and fall in the parking lot once, sued me before I could bat an eyelash.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I don't think Miss Daniels is going to sue anybody.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What's that?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Just some peroxide. I want to clean out the cut.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: So you're a lawyer.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: That's right. What are you doing in Bodega Bay?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Do you practice here?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: No, San Francisco. What are you...?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What kind of law?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Criminal.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Is that why you'd like to see everyone behind bars?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Not everyone, Miss Daniels.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Only violators and practical jokers.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: That's right.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Ouch!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'm sorry.  What are you doing up here?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Didn't you see the lovebirds?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You came all the way up here to bring me those birds?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: To bring your sister those birds. You said it was her birthday. Besides, I was coming up anyway.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: To see a friend of mine.  Will you please be careful?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'm sorry.  Who's your friend?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Why...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Annie. Annie Hayworth.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Well, well, small world. Annie Hayworth.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: How do you know Annie?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: We... we went to school together. College.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Did you! Imagine that! How long will you be staying?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Just a few... just a day or two... the weekend.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I think we'll have to shave the hair. Deke, have you got a razor?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh, no you don't!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: It's still bleeding a little. Here, let me put this on.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Bend your head down. This little Band-Aid won't show.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: So you came up to see Annie, huh?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I don't believe you.  I think you came up to see me.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Why would I want to see you, of all people?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I don't know. But it seems to me you must have gone to a lot of trouble to find out who I was, and where I lived and...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It was no trouble at all. I simply called my father's paper. Besides, I was coming up here anyway, I already told you...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You like me, huh?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I loathe you. You have no manners. And you're arrogant and conceited and... I wrote you a letter about it, in fact, but I tore it up.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What did it say?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: None of your business.  Am I still bleeding?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Can't see a thing.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I can't say I like your seagulls much, either. I come all the way up here to...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: But you were coming up anyway, remember?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I was! And all I get for my pains is a... a... a hole in the head!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Right next to the one you already had.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Look, Mr. Brenner...

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: I thought I saw your car. What are you doing in town?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Mother, I'd like you to meet...

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: A what?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Melanie Daniels. Melanie, my mother.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: How do you do, Miss Daniels?  Acknowledge a what?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: A delivery, Mother. Miss Daniels brought some birds from San Francisco.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Oh. I see.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: For Cathy. For her birthday. By the way, where is she?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Across at Brinkmeyer's.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Miss Daniels is staying for the weekend. In fact, I've already invited her to dinner tonight.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: After all, you did go to the trouble of bringing up those birds.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: You did say birds?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes, lovebirds. We couldn't let you...

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Lovebirds, I see.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: ...get away without thanking you in some small way. After all, you haven't even met Cathy and you are staying for the weekend...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, but...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You are, aren't you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Certainly, but...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Then it's settled. What time is dinner, Mother?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Seven o'clock, same as usual.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'll pick you up, Miss Daniels. Where are you staying?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: With... with Annie, of course.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Of course, how stupid of me. A quarter to seven, will that be all right?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Annie... Annie may have made other plans. I'll have to see. Besides, I can find my own way.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You're sure now? You won't hire a boat or anything?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'm sure.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Seven o'clock then.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Maybe.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: We'll be waiting. How's your head now?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It's nothing, Mrs. Brenner. A gull hit me, that's all.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Did you find her all right?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, I did.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I was wondering...

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: That sign.  Do you think I could have the room for a single night?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Well, I'd really hope to rent it for...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I would appreciate it. I've tried everywhere in town, and they're all full.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Where's your bag? In the car?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: It's utilitarian, I'll say that for it.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I just picked up some things for the night at the general store. You see, I hadn't planned on spending much time here.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Yes, I know. Did something unexpected crop up?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.  May I use your phone? I'd like to call home.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Why don't you come in then?  I was just about to mix a martini.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Don't they ever stop migrating?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Hi!

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Miss Daniels?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: They're beautiful! They're just what I wanted! Is there a man and a woman? I can't tell which is which.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well, I suppose...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Hi. Annie had no plans, huh? I'm glad you came. Are you hungry?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Famished.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Dinner's just about ready.  We were out back looking at the chickens. Something seems to be wrong with them.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: There's nothing wrong with those chickens, Mitch. I'm going to call Fred Brinkmeyer right now.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Chickens won't eat.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: He sold the feed to me, didn't he?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Caviat emptor, Mother. Let the buyer beware.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Whose side are you on?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'm simply quoting the law.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Never mind the law. Cathy, you can start serving the soup.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: This won't take a minute, Miss Dan...  The chicken feed. The three bags I brought.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Well, it's just no good. The chickens won't eat it.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: He got a call from Dan Fawcett a little while ago. His chickens won't eat, either.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: It's what you said, Mom. Mr. Brinkmeyer's feed is no good.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: You don't think they're getting sick, do you, Mitch?

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: I still don't understand how you knew I wanted lovebirds.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Your brother told me.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Then you knew Mitch in San Francisco, is that right?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, not exactly.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Mitch knows lots of people in San Francisco. Of course, they're mostly hoods.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Cathy!

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Well, Mom, he's the first to admit it.  He spends half his day in the detention cells at the Hall of Justice.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: In a democracy, Cathy, everyone is entitled to a fair trial. Your brother's practice...

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Mom, please, I know all the democracy jazz. They're still hoods.  I mean, even twice would be overdoing it, don't you think?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Why did he shoot her?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: He was watching a ball game on television.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: His wife changed the channel.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Is smoking fun?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh, I suppose so.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Could I have a puff?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I don't think your mother would like that.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: When I grow up, I'm gonna smoke like a chimney! I'll be eleven tomorrow, you know.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I know.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Are you coming to my party?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I don't think so.  I have to get back to San Francisco.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Don't you like us?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Darling, of course I do!

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Don't you like Bodega Bay?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I don't know yet.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Mitch likes it very much. He comes up every weekend, you know, even though he has his own apartment in the city. He says San Francisco is just an ant hill at the foot of a bridge.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I guess it does get a little hectic at times.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: If you do decide to come, don't say I told you about it. It's supposed to be a surprise party.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: You see, they've got this whole complicated thing figured out where I'm going over to Michele's for the afternoon, and Michele's mother is going to say she has a headache and would I mind very much if she took me home. Then, when we get back here, all of the kids'll jump out!  Won't you come? Won't you please come?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I don't think so, Cathy.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: She's a charming girl, isn't she, Mitch?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes, very.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: And certainly pretty.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: How long have you known her?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I told you. We met yesterday.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: In a bird shop.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: She was selling birds.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: No. I only led her into believing I believed she was... Mother, it's really very complicated.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: But she did buy the lovebirds and then brought them all the way...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Mother, where did you go to law school?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: She's very rich, isn't she?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I suppose so. Her father owns a big newspaper in San Francisco.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: You'd think he could manage to keep her name out of print. She's always mentioned in the columns, Mitch.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I know, Mother.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: She is the one who jumped into that fountain in Rome last summer, isn't she?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes, Mother.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Perhaps I'm old-fashioned.  I know it was supposed to be very warm there, Mitch, but... well... actually... well, the newspaper said she was naked.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I know, Mother.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: It's none of my business, of course, but when you bring a girl like that to...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Mother?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I think I can handle Melanie Daniels by myself.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Well...  So long as you know what you want, Mitch.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I know exactly what I want, Mother.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You'll be able to find your way back, won't you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh, yes.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Will I be seeing you again?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: San Francisco's a long way from here.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'm in San Francisco five days a week. With a lot of time on my hands. I'd like to see you.  Maybe we could go swimming or something. Mother tells me you like to swim.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: How does Mother know what I like to do?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I guess she and I read the same gossip columns.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh. That. Rome.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Mmmm. I like to swim. We might get along very...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: In case you're interested, I was pushed into that fountain.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Without any clothes on?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: With all my clothes on!  The newspaper that ran the story happens to be a rival of my father's paper.  Anything they said...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You were just a poor, innocent victim of circumstance, huh?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'm neither poor nor innocent, but the truth of that particular...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: The truth is you were running around with a pretty wild crowd...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, but...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: ...who didn't much care for propriety or convention or...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: ...the opinions of others, and you went right along with them, isn't that the truth?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, that's the truth. But I was pushed into that fountain, and that's the truth, too.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Sure. Do you really know Annie Hayworth?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No.  At least, I didn't until I came up here.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: So you didn't go to school together.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: And you didn't come up here to see her.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You were lying.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, I was lying.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Did you really write a letter to me? Or was that a lie, too?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I wrote the letter.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What did it say?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It said, "Dear Mr. Brenner, I think you need those lovebirds, after all. They may help your personality." That's what it said.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: But you tore it up.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Because it seemed stupid and foolish.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Like jumping into a fountain in Rome!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I told you what happened in Rome!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Do you expect me to believe...?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I don't give a damn what you believe!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'd still like to see you.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I think it could be fun.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: That might have been good enough in Rome last summer. But it's not good enough now.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: It is for me.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: But not for me.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What do you want ?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I thought you knew! I want to go through life laughing and beautiful and jumping into fountains naked! Good night!

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Miss Daniels? Is that you?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Hi.  Is something wrong? Is that cut beginning to bother you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, it's not the cut that's bothering me.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Would you like some brandy?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: If you have some, I'd...

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I'll get it, sit down, Miss Daniels. Do you want a sweater or something? A quilt?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, thank you.  Won't you call me Melanie?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: All right.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Thank you.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: It gets a little chilly here at night sometimes. Especially if you're over near the bay.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Well, how'd your evening go?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Did you meet Lydia?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Or would you rather I changed the subject?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I think so.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: How do you like our little hamlet?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I despise it.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Well, I don't suppose it offers much to the casual visitor. Unless you're thrilled by a collection of shacks on a hillside. It takes a while to get used to.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Where are you from originally, Annie?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: San Francisco.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: How'd you happen to come here?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Oh, someone invited me up for the weekend a long time ago.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Look, I see no reason for being coy about this. It was Mitch Brenner.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I guess you knew that, anyway.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I suspected as much.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: You needn't worry. It's over and done with. A long time ago.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Annie -- there's nothing between Mitch and me.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Isn't there?  Maybe there isn't. Maybe there's never anything between Mitch and any girl.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I think I'll have some of that, too.  And then, one weekend, he asked me up to meet Lydia.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: When was this?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Four years ago. Of course, that was shortly after his father died.  Things may be different now.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Different?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: With Lydia.  Did she seem a trifle distant?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: A trifle.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Then maybe it isn't different at all. You know, her attitude nearly drove me crazy. I simply couldn't understand it.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: When I got back to San Francisco I spent days trying to figure out just what I'd done to displease her.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: And what had you done?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Nothing! I simply existed. So what was the answer? A jealous woman, right? A clinging possessive mother.  Wrong. With all due respect to Oedipus, I don't think that was the case at all.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Then what was it?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Lydia liked me, you see. That was the strange part of it. In fact, now that I'm no longer a threat, we're very good friends.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Then why did she object to you?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Because she was afraid.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Afraid you'd take Mitch?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Afraid I'd give Mitch.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I don't understand.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Afraid of any woman who'd give Mitch the only thing Lydia can give him -- love.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Annie, that adds up to a jealous, possessive woman.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: No, I don't think so. She's not afraid of losing her son, you see.  She's only afraid of being abandoned.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Someone ought to tell her she'd be gaining a daughter.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: She already has a daughter.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What about Mitch? Didn't he have anything to say about this?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I can understand his position. He went through a lot with Lydia after his father died. He didn't want to risk going through it all over again.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I see.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: So it ended. Not immediately, of course. I went back to San Francisco, and I still saw Mitch every now and then... but we both knew it was finished.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Then what are you doing here in Bodega Bay?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: You get straight to the point, don't you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'm sorry. Forgive me.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: No, that's all right, I don't mind. I came up here for two reasons. To begin with, I was bored with my job in San Francisco. I was teaching at a private school there... well, you know, you probably went to one yourself.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Then you know. Little girls in brown beanies. Deadly. Here I have a life. I'll go into that classroom on Monday morning, and I'll look out at twenty- five upturned little faces, and each of them will be saying, 'Yes, please give me what you have.'  That's the first reason.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: And the second?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: You see, I still like him a hell of a lot. That's rare, I think. I don't want to lose his friendship... ever.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Hello?  Oh, hello. No, no, I wasn't asleep. What is it?  It's Mitch. For you.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: He's waiting.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Good night, Mitch.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: He wants me to go to Cathy's party tomorrow afternoon.  I said I would.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I'll be going, too, to help out. It should be fun, Melanie.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It seems so pointless.  My luggage.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Pretty. Did you get that at Brinkmeyer's?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Do you think I should go?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: That's up to you.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It's really up to Lydia, isn't it?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Never mind Lydia. Do you want to go?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Then go.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Thank you, Annie.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Is someone there?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Is anyone there?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Look.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Ohhh. Oh, the poor thing. He probably lost his way in the dark.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: But... it isn't dark, Annie.  There's a full moon.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I really shouldn't have any more. I'm a little tipsy already.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'm trying to get you to stay for dinner. We're going to have a lot of roast left over.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I couldn't possibly. I have to get back.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Cheers.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Cheers.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What's in this? Nitro-glycerin?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Why do you have to rush off? What's so important in San Francisco?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Well... I have to get to work tomorrow morning, for one thing.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You have a job?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I have several jobs.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What do you do?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I do different things on different days.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Like what?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: On Mondays and Wednesdays, I work for the Travelers' Aid. At the airport.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Helping travelers.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: And on Tuesdays, I take a course in General Semantics at Berkeley.  That's not a job, of course. I just take it because...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What about Thursdays and Fridays?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: On Thursdays I have my meeting and lunch.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: And Fridays? What do you do then?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Nothing.  I go to bird shops on Fridays.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I'm glad you do.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Do you know what I was doing in that shop?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I have an aunt, you see. Aunt Tessa. She's seventy years old, and veddy prim and strait-laced.  She's coming back from Europe at the end of the month, and I'm going to give her a myna bird that'll talk to her.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What'll it say?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: You'll think me very bold, sir.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: No, tell me.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: That's silly, isn't it?  Teaching a bird to shock my aunt. That's just silly and childish.  Maybe I ought to go join the other children.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: All right then, here we go.  Three! Go get 'em, Cathy!

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: No touching allowed!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: That's the darnest thing thing I've ever seen in my life.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Are they gone?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: They're gone, Mother.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Well... well, is everyone all right?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I think he got a little scratch, Mother.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Children, they were only seagulls.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: They must have been after the food, Mother.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: They didn't touch anything.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Who was 'it?' You were 'it,' weren't you, Cathy?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: You look a little shaken.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I... I am.  Mitch, is... Mitch, this isn't usual, is it? The gull yesterday when I was in the boat, and the one last night at Annie's, and now...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Last night? What do you mean?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: A gull smashed into Annie's front door.  Mitch... what's happening?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Look, do you have to go back to Annie's?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, I have my things in the car.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Then stay and have something to eat before you start back. I'd feel a lot better.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Do you want some mustard with this?

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Why didn't Annie stay for dinner?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: She said something about having to get home to take a call from her mother back East.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Oh. Where d'you want the coffee?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Take it into the living room, would you, hon?

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: What's the matter with them?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: What's the matter with all the birds?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Hurry up with the rest, Mitch. I'm sure Miss Daniels wants to get on her way.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: I think you ought to stay the night, Melanie.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: We've got an extra room upstairs and everything.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: If I go across to Santa Rosa I'll come onto the freeway much earlier.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Yeah, and the freeway's well-lighted, isn't it, Mitch?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yeah, but she'll be hitting all that traffic going back to San Francisco.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Did you put the cover on that cage, Mom?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Yes, I did.

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: Just listen to them!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Some cream?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'll get it.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Mitch...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Mitch!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Cathy, get some matches!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Mitch! The curtains!

Speaker: cathy
Dialogue: It's working! The fire's working!

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: That's a chimney swift, all right.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: We know what it is, Al.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Well, these birds live in chimneys, you know.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Not by the thousands.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: No, I gotta admit this is peculiar.  Did you have a light burning or something.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Yes, but the curtains were drawn.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: 'Cause sometimes birds are attracted by light, you know.  Sure is a peculiar thing.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What are we going to do about it, Al?

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: I don't think I get you, Mitch. Do about what?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Well...  Well... these birds attacked us.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: What's more likely, they got in the room and was just panicked, that's all.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: All right, I'll grant you a bird'll panic in an enclosed room. But, they didn't just get in. They came in! Right down that chimney.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: My wife found a bird in the back seat of her car once.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: These birds were...

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: What I'm trying to say, Mitch, is these things happen sometimes, you know? Ain't much we can do about it.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Tell him about the party.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: That's right. We had a party here this afternoon for Cathy. Her birthday.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Oh, yeah, yeah.  How old is she now?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Eleven. In the middle of the party, some gulls came down at the children. And Miss Daniels was attacked by a gull just yesterday after...

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Yeah.  Were the kids bothering them or something? 'Cause sometimes they'll do that, you know. If you make any kind of disturbance near them, they'll just come after you. I seen that plenty of times myself.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: The children were playing a game, Al. Those gulls attacked without...

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Now, Lydia, 'attack' is a pretty strong word, don't you think? I mean, birds just don't go around attacking people without no reason, you know what I mean? The kids just probably scared them, that's all.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: These birds attacked!

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Now, that'd be pretty silly, wouldn't it?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Does this room look silly?

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: No, you got quite a mess here, I'll admit that.  You want some help cleaning up?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I can handle it myself.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'll take Cathy up to bed.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Are you staying?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I think I should, don't you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'll get my things from the car. Do you want to walk with me, Cathy?

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Well, if there's anything else I can do, Mitch...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Thanks, Al. We'll be all right.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Goodnight, Lydia.

Speaker: malone
Dialogue: Sure is peculiar, I got to say that for it.

Speaker: lydia's voice
Dialogue: Mitch! Mitch! Mitch, I'm going to drop Cathy off now.

Speaker: mitch's voice
Dialogue: Okay.

Speaker: lydia's voice
Dialogue: I'll probably drive over to the Fawcett farm. Do you need anything in town?

Speaker: mitch's voice
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Mitch?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Mitch?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Chee-chee-chee-chee-chee.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I wanted to change my shirt.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: It smelled of the fire.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I think I've got it all figured out, by the way.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Really? Tell me about it.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It's an uprising.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Of birds?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Certainly, of birds.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It all started several months ago with a peasant sparrow up in the hills, a malcontent. He went around telling all the other sparrows that human beings weren't fit to rule this planet, preaching wherever anyone would listen...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Growing a beard...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, of course, he had to have a beard! 'Birds of the world, unite!' he kept saying, over and over...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: So they united.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Not at first. Oh yes, a few sparrows out for kicks...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Well, they'll go along with anything.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Sure. But eventually, even the more serious-minded birds began to listen. "Why should humans rule?" they asked themselves.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Hear!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Why should we submit ourselves to their domination?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Hear, hear!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: And all the while, that sparrow was getting in his little messages. Birds of the world, unite!

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Take wing!

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: You have nothing to lose but your feathers.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What it was, probably...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Mmm?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: They're probably hungry, that's all. This was a bad summer. They eat berries and... and nuts, you know, and the hills are all burned out, so they're probably searching for food wherever they can get it.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: With my little sparrow leading team.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: It's so damn quiet out there.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It was like that yesterday.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What do you mean?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: After the gulls attacked.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: I hadn't thought of that.  And then the swifts came.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: It makes you feel as if they're... they're waiting or... resting... or....

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: No, they're having a meeting, Melanie. Your sparrow is standing on a soap box and...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: ...waving his little wings...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: They were angry, Mitch. They came out of the chimney in fury.  I had the feeling they wanted each and every one of us dead.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Melanie, Melanie...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'm frightened, Mitch.

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: No, no...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: I'm frightened and confused and I... I think I want to go back to San Francisco where there are buildings and... and concrete and...

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: Melanie...

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: ...everything I know.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Oh damn it, why did you have to walk into that shop?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Dan?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Dan?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Hi, there!

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Is Mr. Fawcett home?

Speaker: farmhand
Dialogue: I think so, ma'm. His missus is in Santa Cruz, but he ought to be here.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Have you seen him this morning?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Thank you!

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Here, chick, chick, chick, chick. Here, chick, chick, chick, chick.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Dan?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Dan? Are you home?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Dan?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Dan?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Dan? Are you in there?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: mitch
Dialogue: That was Al on the phone. He wants me to meet him out at the Fawcett place. Says some detectives from Santa Rosa'll be there in a little while.  Will you be all right here?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes. I was just taking her in some tea.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Be careful. Please.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No, it's me, Mrs. Brenner. I thought you might like some tea.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Oh, thank you.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Where's Mitch?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Al Malone wanted him out at the Fawcett farm.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Why? Didn't Al believe my story?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: He was calling from the farm, Mrs. Brenner.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Then he saw.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: He must have. He sent for the Santa Rosa police.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: What good will they do?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Do you think Cathy's all right?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Cathy. At the school.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Yes, I'm sure she's fine.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: Do I sound foolish to you?

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: I keep seeing Dan Fawcett's face.  All the windows were broken. In Dan's bedroom. All the windows.

Speaker: melanie
Dialogue: Try not to think of that, Mrs. Brenner.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: I wish I were a stronger person. There is a long awkward silence. She sips at her tea reflectively.

Speaker: lydia
Dialogue: I lost my husband four years ago, you know.  Do you think Cathy's all right?

Speaker: melanie
